page.lettertext:
fol.29r
May it please your good L: upon conference had with
M
r
Barnevelt
, and
with some others of
e State, for
e advancem
t
of my service, I see this
message of her
Ma
tie
doth trouble them exceedingly. For they seeme
very loath to returne a naked answear, and to give her good con-
tent they pleade unabilitie. But their greatest doubt is this, whether
in this conjuncture (as they terme it) and as
e present State stan-
deth both with them and the Enemie, and those
at nowe endevor
to drawe them to a peace, considering also
at this yeeres contribu-
tion is not accorded by
e
Provinces,
it were convenient to impart
to
e people her Ma
ties
demaundes. For they saye they can doe
nothing without their approbation, for contenting of her Ma
tie
and to publish unto them what her Hig
es
requyreth, they holde it
very daungerous in this p
nt
concurrence of soe sundrie great
and weightie affaires. They have bin often together to de-
termine upon it, but they are at no conclusion. I expect
every day when some shalbe deputed, to come in conference w
th
me: and by
at, as I thincke, I shall ghesse somewhat neere, both
howe they will frame their p
nt
aunswear, and what successe in
e end I am lyke to have.
Coronel Stuart
hath bin with
me, and in co
m
unication hath declared,
at his co
m
ing to
e
States
is for no other cause, but First to renew an
d
alliance
beetween
e
King
and these Contreis, such as hath bin established
in former tymes: secondly to acquaint them very thorowly with
the present State of Scotland: and then lastly to request
their advise, together with their succo
r
: without proposing
wherein, but according to their power, and soe as they shall
fynde
e necessitie of
e Kinge, which toucheth them in lyke ma
n
er
if his Enemies should prevyale. And this he pretendes to
be a course, which
e King is forced to take. For saith he, sith
he cannot be supported
by
e Q. of England
whome he sawe his Estate but
slenderly regarded, to whome should he seeke but to
e people
fol.29v
of these Provinces? Through
e helpe of those discourses w[e have]
receaved of
S
r
Robert Cecil
, I was stoared of good matter [to an-]
swear his complaint: which he uttered notwithstanding [.]
any passion, and with a preface before full of duetifull wor[.]
pect to her Ma
tie
. Howbeyt I sawe by
at little, and by [.]
conjectures,
at he useth other phrases in other companie abr[road]
I have done what I can, to feele
e States disposition, to g[.]
Kinge, but I can not yet perceave
at they are bent therw[ith]
for want of affection (for undoubtedly that waye they ar[e]
but if they would relieve him, it muste be only with money, [.]
could devise to come by it, I doe not doubt but some good [.]
be graunted her Hig
es
and to content
e King besydes, there [.]
of probabilitie
at they will any way be able. It is also [.]
by
e Coronel unto me
at to strenghten
e League between the [.]
these Contreis, he hath in charge to motion a match betw[een the
Earl]
of Orchney
, and
e
La: Emilia
Co: Maurices
sister. Whi[ch .]
them saye heere is labor lost, for
at
e Erles dwelling is f[.]
as it is saide, he hath no assurance of
e
Orcades
, because [.]
claymed by
e Kinges of
Denmarke,
and it was a late spe[.]
Q. of Scotland
, that she hoped her sonne should enjoy [.]
where your L: puttes me in minde, by a l
re
of
e 25 of [.]
suite of
e
marchants adventurers
, about
e taring of [.]
and of
e abuse of those of Middleborgh, about
e [currency] [.]
monies: for this later point, I have dealt therein he[.]
Middleborgh,
and it was carefully followed by
M
r
Gilpin
[.]
hath and will certefie what reformation therein is intended [.]
States. And soe for
e former I doe but watch an [.]
to reco
m
end it with
e soonest. For now I am certaine I should [.]
come out of season, to cause them to assemble for a matter
of
at qualitie. And where your L: would be informed [of]
e nombers remayning of
e English regiment in
e states paye, I [.]
fol.30r
by inquirie of their Co
m
issarie, by whome they were mustered very lately,
at he re
c
kned 900 or more very able and soliderlyke men: and
at of
e
residue, many are runne away, and many gone with license, and
also dyvers consumed w
t
sickenesse, and in service. We are
no longer nowe in doubt, but
at
e Castel and towne of
Huy
, or Hoy,
in
e lande of Luyck, are surprised and kept with 600 foote, and
200 horse of this Contrey,
Harawguieres
e Gouverno
r
of
Breda
co
m
aunding in
e Castel and an other Cap
t
in
e towne.
If
e place be soe stronge by nature, as every man reportes, or can
be strenghtened by Arte and industrie, beyng situat, as it is, upon
soe famous a river, and in
e middest of soe many riche Provinces,
it will undoubtedly be brought, to yelde a large revenue, by meanes
of new contributions, and dyvers kndes of impositions,
at maye be
raised in tyme upon
e Contrey, and
e River. Moreover
e
passadge too and fro, between
e Enemie and
Italy
, will now in
a manner be closed up cleane, the sooner, through
e aide of
e
D.
of Bouillon
, who hath his Armie there at hand within 6 dutche
myles. In effect it is thought
at
e taking of this place
will cause a great alteration in
e actions of this Contrey, and
I hope it will advaunce
at which I am to negotiat.
The defeat of our horsemen, whereof I writte in my laste, hath bin
verified unto us; but there were noe more, as nowe we are ad-
vertised, but 4 Cornets i n all, and we have lost but 70 horse,
which I thincke will prove a favorable reporte./ I doe also
understand
at
e States have a purpose (if they finde upon tryall
at Huy is stronge and tenable, to take and fortifie, some place
about
e middeway between it and Breda, which will adde a great
assurance to
e holding of
e Towne, and doe
e Enemie more an-
noyance. The bishop of
Liege
hath sent his Ambassado
rs
hither, to expostulat this taking of Huy, beyng a neutrall place
but they have had no audience as yet. The Scottish Kinge
hath given co
m
ission to
e Consul of
e Scottish marchants, resi-
ding in
Tervere
in
Zeland,
whom they otherwise terme conservator
of theyr priviledges to continue
to
heere as his Ambassador Ligger
fol.30v
w
th
e States: his name is
Robert Devinston
, a man broug[ht]
e studie of
e Civill Lawes, and in travel. It is a[dvertised]
hither by
e Agent of
e States residing in Scotland [that the]
King there of late, hath sett his moneis at a higher [.]
then their value, and hath withall procured by his [.]
out of Zeland ten thowsand poundes sterling to be co[.]
him in coyne, which some interpret heere to be a spe[.]
of a great alteration lyke to ensue.
Knowing no [.]
sydes worth
e wryting to yo
r
L. I take my humble l[eave.]
